The project seeks to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture and tourism businesses to recognize evident climate risk issues in tourism operations and adopt appropriate adaptation measures to address them.

title.narrative: Quarterly Progress Report 2016 Q1 TAP 60884 Final

description.narrative: Policy Environment for Tourism Adaptation to Climate Change in the Maldives
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of tourism related policies strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water, waste, energy and infrastructure management. 2. existance of a platform to promote investment CCA in tourism sector. 3. No of partnership projects with tourist operators and tourism associated communities which reduce their vulnerabilities to climate hazards, initiated 4. No of partnership projects with tourist operators and tourism associated communities which reduce their vulnerabilities to climate hazards, completed
Increase adaptive capacity of the tourism sector in Maldives to respond to the impacts of climate change and invest in appropriate, no-regrets adaptation measures.
Number of tourism-related policies, strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water, waste, energy and infrastructure management

comment.narrative: Existing tourism policies, laws and regulations do not integrate climate risk information and require/enforce private sector investments in climate change adaptation measures
An Addendum to the Maldives National Building Code and its associated compliance documents is developed, disseminated and adopted by all tourism resorts.

With the recommendation of Ministry of Housing and Infrastructure MoT has plans to incorporate compliance standards based on the Addendum to the MNBC in the Tourism regulations for tourist facilities development. Having provided technical recommendations through the study reports and publications made by the project, additional plans are underway for new products which have not been developed. This includea developing a strategic plan for Marina Development plan for Maldives which will identify zones, and standards for marina incorporating climate change risks. Ministry of Tourism has been given additional responsibilities in overseeing and implementation of environmental impacts assessment (EIA) for tourism projects. . As this is a technical area which would require capacity building within the Ministry TAP will be facilitating developing appropriate guidelines and SOPs on this aspect to increase capacity of the Ministry of Tourism.

description.narrative: Number of tourism operators who invest in concrete initiatives that enhance their climate risk resilience, based on guidance provided by the project.

comment.narrative: Most tourism operators do not draw on, or comply with, consistent guidance for no-regrets adaptation measures to increase resilience to climate-related risks and extreme events.
At least 10 tourism resorts invest in new climate risk management initiatives which increase their resilience to climate-related risks and reduce economic losses from extreme events

TAP has allocated small grants amounting to US$ 252,500 to 13 small grant projects being undertaken in 10 Atolls and in 11 different islands.
From the total amount budgeted, a total of US 39,416 has been spent. US 185,675 has been budgeted to spend in 2015 (Q3 and Q4) and US 177,589 has been budgeted to spend in 2016 (Q1 and Q2). The grant projects include ;
- Sustainable Water Management and Community Awareness in Maalhos Island, Baa Atoll.
- Boduhuraa Solid Waste Management Project
- Promotion of Compost Production for Solid Waste Management and Climate Change Adaptation in Agriculture Industry of Gan, Laamu Atoll by Gan Development Society.
- Protecting and conservation of fresh water lens to deal with droughts by adapting hydroponics and water dripping system in farms.
- Heat Recovery Pilot Alternative Mechanisms to Fossil Fuel Consumption for Sea Transportation
Coral Garden in the Island of Fainu in Raa Atoll
- Eco-Tour Mangroves in Maalhendhoo island in Noonu atoll.
- Coral Garden (Culture and conserve marine resources and improve livelihoods through sustainable eco-tourism) in N. Maafaru island
- Creating a Habitat for Reviving Threatened Seabird Population by Sea Explorers
- Recycling of Engine Oil and Stop Contamination by tourist dive operator, Maldives Inc
- Towards Sustainable Energy for Adaptation to Climate Change in Tourist Resorts of Maldives" in the atolls of Male Atoll, Alif Ali, Alif Dhaal and Meemu
- Waste to Energy by Compact Bio Gas by Hakuraa Huraa Resort
- Adaptation to Coral Reef Bleaching Events in Baa atoll

description.narrative: Number of tourism-associated communities which reduce their vulnerability to climate hazards, based on investment activities facilitated by the project.

comment.narrative: Limited examples of cooperation between tourism resorts and communities on joint risk management efforts.

At least 10 tourism-associated communities reduce the vulnerability of their water, waste, energy and infrastructure management systems, based on partnerships, guidance and private sector investment facilitated by the project.

Three tourism-associated communities have reduced their vulnerabilities in the areas of waste management (in K. Boduhuraa in association with a neighbouring tourist resort and Four Seasons Resort), freshwater management in the island of Maalhos and water conservation and sustainable agriculture in the island of Thoddoo in cooperation with tourist guesthouse operator.

description.narrative: Strengthened adaptive capacity of the tourism sector to reduce risks to climate-induced economic losses.
Number of island resorts and tourism operators with increased capacity to reduce risks of climate variability.

comment.narrative: Most tourism operators are concerned about their increased vulnerability to climate change, but do not draw on, or comply with, consistent guidance for effective no-regrets adaptation measures to increase resilience.

By the end of the project, 100% of relevant MTAC staff and at least 60% of all trained tourism operators recognize the economic impacts of climate change on tourism operations and know the cost/benefit aspects of different adaptation investments

Training conducted in Climate risk financing solutions. The conference ended on 5th June 2015.
Training for MoT/MTAC staff on climate adaptation was held on 12th February 2015. All sections of the ministry participated including 17 male and 30 female staff. Training for Trainers consultancy underway for educators. Training will commence in August 2015 in 5 atolls including school teachers and councilors The training is to be conducted based on Climate Change Adaptation and Environment Monitoring on Tourism Dependent Communities.
A presentation was made by TAP Project Manager in the opening Session of the Regional Tourism Ministers Conference organized by the Ministry of Tourism and World Tourism Organization UNWTO held in Bandos Island Resort on 3rd June 2015. The Conference was attended by HEP the President Mr. Yameen Abdul Gayyoom, the Secretary General of UNWTO Dr. Taleb Rifai, Cabinet Ministers and Head of Independent Insttutions and Officials of the government of Maldives, Asia and the Pacific Ministers among UNWTO member states and participants of the Regional Commission meetings of the UNWTO. A total of 152 delegates comprising of 116 foreign delegates and 36 local delegates participated in the conference opening session.

description.narrative: Number of new investment projects in the tourism industry that are designed and implemented in accordance with revised tourism policies and planning frameworks.

comment.narrative: National policies and laws regulating tourism operations do not contain functional references to climate-proofing and fail to incentivise private sector investment in climate risk management.
By the end of the project, an Addendum to the Maldives National Building Code and its associated compliance documents is developed, disseminated and adopted by all new tourism development projects.
None. However, the addendum and compliance documents will be incorporated in the tourism regulations and awareness programmes are planned for year 2016.

description.narrative: Reduced vulnerability of at least 10 tourism operations and 10 tourism-associated communities to the adverse effects of climate change
Number of tourism-related policies, strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water, waste, energy and infrastructure management

comment.narrative: Existing tourism policies, laws and regulations do not integrate climate risk information and require/enforce private sector investments in climate change adaptation measures

By the end of the project, at least 10 tourism-associated communities have planned and implemented concrete adaptation projects which reduce the vulnerability of their infrastructure, water, waste, land-use planning or energy management systems to climate-related hazards

A total of 13 small grants projects are ongoing by end June 2015. These 13 projects are distributed among 10 Atolls, which are, R. Atoll, A. Atoll, N. Atoll, Male Atoll, A.Dh Atoll, A. A Atoll, B. Atoll, L. Atoll and G. A Atoll. Among these 10 atolls there are 11 islands that have ongoing projects. The total amount budgeted for small grants is USD 252,500 and USD 39,416 has been disbursed. The remaining funds are planned for utilization in 2015( USD 185,675) and 2016 (USD 177,589). Additional funds on this activity is planned to be directed to the ongoing grants projects for project enhancement activities depending on the progress.

description.narrative: Number of tourism-related policies, strategies and action plans which stimulate investment by tourism operators in climate resilient water, waste, energy and infrastructure management

comment.narrative: Existing tourism policies, laws and regulations do not integrate climate risk information and require/enforce private sector investments in climate change adaptation measures
By the end of the project, at least 10 tourism operators are adopting project guidance to invest in climate- resilient water, wastewater, solid waste and infrastructure management systems

13 small grants projects are being undertaken by the project which would strengthen capacity of tourism operators and associated communities. 4th Tourism Master plan developed with strategic direction for climate adaptation in the tourism sector for the period 2013-2017.
Additional 6 TAP study reports have been published by the project. The documents were used in the TAP Climate Adaptation Forum held in 2015. Each of the reports identified current status and recommendations for climate adaptation in that specific area. The reports are also available from the website of the Ministry of Tourism to download.

description.narrative: Transfer of climate risk financing solutions to public and private sector tourism institutions
Number of staff from government agencies and tourism operators who have increased knowledge of climate risk financing instruments.

comment.narrative: Government entities and tourism sector operators in Maldives have limited knowledge of climate risk financing products and their potential application in the Maldivian context.

At project completion, all representatives in relevant MTAC, MEE & MHI departments and all representatives of different tourist facility groups (including resorts, safari boats and hotel operators) are aware of climate risk financing and transfer instruments and their potential in the Maldivian context.

A feasibility study on index-based insurance and risk polling options (Activity 3.2.) and feasibility study on micro-insurance for tourism associated communities to buffer climate related shocks from extreme events (Activity 3.3) have been completed and Training Sessions have been conducted with private sector, private sectoe, local councils and all the existing insurance companies operating in the Maldives. Training sessions have been completed in the 4th quarter of 2014 as reported in the previous reporting period. Furthermore, 2 pilot project proposals were developed in consultation with stake holders attended by private sector and the public sector including the insurance companies working in the Maldives.

description.narrative: Type and number of climate risk financing products and services (such as index-based insurance) available to public and private sector entities.

comment.narrative: No climate risk financing products and services are available on the Maldives market.
By the end of the project, the Government of Maldives has access to at least one climate risk financing solution

Two pilot project proposals have been developed based on previous reports and discussions Developing and implementing activity on potential index-based insurance and risk pooling options and micro insurance for tourism operators associated communities (Activity 3.2.3) has been completed during the first Quarter of 2015.

description.narrative: Increasing climate resilience through an Integrated Water Resource Managment programme in 3 Islands

title.narrative: Evaluation of the Integrated Water Resources Management Project

description.narrative: The primary problem addressed by this project is a significant climate change induced decline freshwater security that is affecting vulnerable communities in Maldives
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Progress towards completion of Integrated Water Resource Management Systems in HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo and GDh. Gadhdhoo 2. Number of staff from water and sewage utility companies trained in the technical principles and skills required to design, implement and maintain climate-resilient and integrated water management systems. 3. % of people living on HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo, and GDh. Gadhdhoo who have uninterrupted access to reliable and safe freshwater supply in extreme climatic conditions

comment.narrative: 1. No Integrated Water Resource Management Systems in HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo and GDh. Gadhdhoo 2. 0 3. 0%
1. Integrated Water Resource Management Systems in HA. Ihavandhoo, ADh. Mahibadhoo and GDh. Gadhdhoo are functioning and defects rectification 2. 30 3. 100%

This is an Initiation Plan. The purpose of the project is to assist to undertake preparatory activities for the LECReD Programme, including the design of the programme framework, developmentof a full-fledged programme.
Communication and Awareness on LECReD
independent political entity
first-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

The programme will assist the Laamu Atoll and its islands to realize low emission and climate resilient development (LECReD). The programme seeks to mainstream LECReD issues into local level development planning
Project to support low emission climate resilient local development in Maldives. It will achieve this by taking an atoll-based approach, focusing on Laamu Atoll
